One of the first things I am pondering as of yesterday is that this trail is like a lifetime that I am walking through. The uphills, the downhills and the flats. Flats, I can stride along without a care in the world. The main thing to remember is that none of those circumstances are going to last. And I've been reminded in life that we just have to keep rolling with everything because it will always change. Things generally never stay bad nor good nor stable! We had dinner last night at Buffalo Wild Wings.Â  Had to leave the hotel about 715 to get to the train station.Â  Got off the train inÂ  Hoboken and took a subway into the city.Â  We did a fair amount of walking, taking in various sights.Â  Interesting, how when I think of NYC I think of fashion trends and beautiful people.Â  That's not what I saw!Â  Any sort of clothing that can be thrown on is being worn and there were very few beautiful people.Â  Us hiker trash fit right in.Â  Another thought occurred to me, if everyone were to put the amount spent on drinks not purchased in a grocery store and brought from home, we'd probably take a chunk out of the national debt!!Â  It was amazing how many had coffees, sodas, etc ranging from $2-$7, I'm sure!Â Â

Very hard to keep track of days and things when I don't have signal.Â  No Bad took off early yesterday morning, but after a long stop at Duncan Donuts, ended up meeting is at the lodge on top of Greylock.Â  We sat outside and had our tents laid out to dry after canning in the grass at the Cheshire camoy site.Â  So much condensation!!Â  Saw several other hikers that had camped together with us.Â  Talked with several people who were really amazed at what we were doing.Â Â Emerald and I set off after lunch having said goodbye to NoBad again.Â  About thirty minutes down the trail, here he comes behind us again having taken a wrong turn!Â  He passed us to hurry and meet his shuttle driver with plans to meet us at the camp site.As we passed through town about to head back in the woods, about 200 yds in front of us (a few hours later) we ran in to him and got to finish it day together.Â Â The camp site was a recent controlled burn area anid not the best place to camp.W got going later than expected today, 745 but only had to go about 12.6 to the shelter.Â  We crossed in to Vermont...Vermud and it lives up to his name!Â  Seems like it could use some trail maintenance to clear the trail and mud is quite deep in random areas.

So not only did we recently walk in to Vermont and stay at the shelter that put us at our halfway point to Katahdin... But tomorrow Emerald and I will hit our 600 miles.Â  So many accomplishments!!Today we had to leave the shelter in a bit of rain but it chatted quickly.Â  Vermont is mostly mud.Â  Apparently there are places that just never dry.Â Â I had a hard time with today's hike.Â  I had a headache most of the day and the only thing I can think of was the long descent on wet rock steps that I had to concentrate on for about forty minutes early on.Â  I just didn't seem to have any gas in my tank.Â  Tomorrow we need to do closer to 18 and I'm dreading it.Â  There still aren't a lot of places to camp so it seems the choices are either super short hikes or long ones.Â Â We plan on going on to town on Monday so the miles are based around getting us close to the road so we can hike about 10 miles Monday morning then hitch in to town, resupply and go to a hostel.Â Â I've contacted my tent company and am hoping I can purchase a rain fly separately and secure my shelter.Â Â I received donation from a FL hiking friend and am very much appreciative!!Â  (Thank you Steve, Brittany will be depositing it soon)!!Â  Also, thank you for putting the word out to the local hiking group.Â Â I've heard Vermont people ask you if you need a ride if they see you in a parking lot.Â  You don't even have to hitch hike!Â  Emerald got offered two rides to town this morning as she took a break in a lot near the trail!Â  I'm hoping we have as much luck Monday morning and get in quickly.Pray or send positive vibes for long, ready miles tomorrow please!!

Wow!Â  The last six days have been crazy.Â  After staying in a hotel in North Woodstock, we shuttled to the trail with Alys Rides.Â  We entered the Whites and it had been the hardest terrain since starting, combining crazy step accent's with rocks, hand over hand bouldering, etc.Â  We did about 11 miles the first day and hit to Kinsman Pond Shelter.Â  Alys Rides brought us food on Sunday that we had purchased a few days earlier.Â  I fell leaving our Resupply and got a pretty good gash and goose egg on my shin.Â  We hiked to Liberty Springs Tent area.Â  I put the Hexamid tent up for the first time on the platform and slept well.Â  We stayed at a hut the next night.Â  Galehead.Â  Stupid expensive bunk house withÂ  breakfast and dinner.Â  The food has to be helicoptered in or carried and they use mostly propane and solar.Â  We couldn't charge phones, shower, no wifi, etc. The next day we hiked to Neuman tent and hut area.Â  I tented, No Bad stayed in the hut again.Â  I put up the tent and it rained.Â  The bathtub area took on water and my stuff got wet.Â  I got in the shelter the next night at Ethan Pond.Â  About four miles before this was a pleasant flat hike that made me wish I were in the south without the terrain up here.Â  One other friend messed up his leg in a fall and another got a concussion.Â  Leaving Neunan about 6am, I solo hiked up over Washington and to Madison to Osgood tent area.Â  Stopped in the huts to dry a bit, warm up and check for leftovers.Â  (You can eat free food if they have any).Â  Pretty tough hike with about 12 miles above tree line.Â  Didn't get many views the whole time I've been in this area, but I'm thankful to not have a storm roll in while above tree line!!Â  I've fallen about seven times since starting the Whites andÂ  presidentals, again very thankful for mostly soft landings and no joint problems.Â  Â Left Osgood first and took a wrong turn, wound up at the road about two miles from where I was supposed to come out.Â  Hitched in to town and called the hostel for a pick up.Â  I'm currently warm and dry.Â  Once again, I need a tent.Â  I can't recommend the Hexamid based on my experience and was told by two others that it was tough to pitch perfect.Â  Now I know!Â  I'm sure I'm missing many stories from this section, but feel free to ask questions!!

This past week has just been unimaginable! I feel like I've been so negative regarding the trail and the weather, but this has certainly been a week where the mental aspect has kicked in and kicked my butt. The tremendous amount of effort it has taken to get over multiple mountains, to see absolutely nothing due to the weather and knowing with each step I could end my hike due to the rain has really impacted me hard. I considered taking a couple of zero days to get my mind right and let the weather pass through however tomorrow is supposed to be a decent day so I will move on. I also considered a way to do my flip now and do some time in the south and then come back up and finish up but that's just more logistics, money and time that I would have to put into this hike and I'd really like to be home at the end of October or sooner. I'm very thankful to have not injured myself to a point that I need to lay up or go home But with each fall, I'm just one position away from that happening. A friend should be ordering my new tent tomorrow and I'm hoping to have it by the weekend or early next week. That will remove a lot of stress!All of what I've experienced so far isn't what I've expected from this hike. I'm thinking a lot has to do with me as I'm older than a lot of the people out here and also, as I'm doing right now I'm in a private room looking at my phone rather than being down with the youngsters watching a movie or talking. But a good hour or two of that time has been sent looking ahead trying to plan the next food resupply, hostile stay to get out of weather and determine two points for the possible tent delivery. I think I'll find less people on trail when I head south as flip-floppers and sobos are the smaller community.Going back to the hutts in the whites, each hut generally has soup and bread, baked goods coffee, tea and lemonade for sale.Â  Our dinner meal consisted of a salad and bread, a tomato bisque soup, pasta marinara and a fried chicken breast as well as a large size cream cheese filled brownie. Breakfast was oatmeal, eggs bacon and pancakes. The food definitely was very good and filling the only downside is the expense for staying in a bunk.When passing through the whites and stopping at campsites, they have a through hiker pass. At the first campsite you pay $10 and receive the pass and your overnight stay. Each additional campsite or shelter that you stay at then is $5 rather than 10 if you were just doing a section hike. A caretaker is at each place maintaining the privy. And there is also discounts on the card for the soup or baked goods as you're passing through the huts.Will be crossing over into Maine soon and I believe we have about 30 miles and 12,000 ft elevation in the next three days. Not big miles, but a lot of work getting up and over the mountains. I'm praying for clear skies and no rain. As of now I believe we expect to overnight in bethel Maine Thursday and it's calling for rain Thursday and Friday.I woke up to find a very generous donation in my Venmo account this morning! Thank you Liz k for your kindness! It certainly comes in handy as I know I will be taking more breaks, more so for my mental health than my physical! :-)

But find out immediately that did weren't allowed.Â  She reached out to me and Brittany have her my house for several days.Â  While there I got a report that Coco is doing great and that she had turned herself in to an outside dog!!Â  She has free access to go in and out and sisterly she is staying out executive to come in for a treat, her meds and food.Â  She was it during fireworks and just laid in her various holes, relaxing!Â  Maybe she knows I'm sleeping outside and wants to be bonded with me!Â  â¤ï¸â¤ï¸Back to Brandi.... Which I desperately need as I split the whole back end of of my black ones.Also, big thanks to Eric for ordering my tent from Big Agnes.Â  I "should" get that at a hostel nextÂ  Thursday shit 75 miles from here.Â  I don't be putting in big miles as I'm trying to hit the hostel in time to get the tent... knowing they get to go back to a cabin, hotel, etc for the night may make some of this hiking easier to manage.Â  Also, you can choose your trails or loops to make the mileage more manageable.Â Â I I started day two about 7 and planned to go just over 15 miles.Â  About mid afternoon, the rain came in.Â  I made it to the shelter and there were two men there.Â  I was thankful for the company.Â  Two more hikers came in and I knew one from my northern hike.Â  I'd met her in the first week, I believe.Â  I hoping to meet up with her for overnights but she was pushing bigger miles to get off trail for a weekend with family.
We have bear poles at the shelters in VA.Â  Tall posts with hooks at the top and a long rod with a hook on the end, chained to the post that you push your bag up and hook it to the hooks on the tall post.Â  I had no problem with this at the first shelter.Â  I put my food up at this shelter and couldn't get it back down the next morning. How long would it have taken me to get my food down had others not been there!!?Â  And should I continue using the poles?Â  What in the heck do I do if I can't get the food down!!?
I set off to go another 15 miles.Â  Again, temps over 100.Â  I dehydrated myself by the time i got to the shelter.Â  I had been walking in open fields directly in the sun for a bit and realized I wasn't sweating or peeing.Â  My ab muscles started cramping.Â  After rehydrating, I continued to the next shelter another 4.4 away.Â  Again, was alone.
The terrain in VA is much easier than up north.... However when people say VA is flat, that's not true.Â  I had to climb 4200 feet of elevation on Thurs.Â  There are some very easy walking portions of the trail, but there are also rock gardens and elevation change.Â  Most are somewhat gradual but continue for awhile so they still can drain your energy.
Friday I decided to stop at a Hostel to look at my map and make a schedule to meet Jo and Liz in the Shenandoahs.Â  I called the hostel in the morning thinking I may decide to spend the night... And found out they closed this week.Â  Ugh!!Â  But they did let me come by and get cooled off, charge my phone and eat a pizza.Â  Just as I decided to start hiking again, the thunder started and i saw a bolt of lightning up on the mountain.Â  That was it, I called another hostel and am staying the night at Stumble Inn.Â  Looks like I'm going to zero tomorrow.Â  The whole week has rain and storms every day.Â  The temps are lower and this means maybe we'll have better water sources... But I'm not overly anxious to go out hiking in a storm.Â  I saw way too many new trees down the last few days from the other storms, I definitely don't want to be under one of them!
I just have to get it through my head that if I don't want to hike,Â  I don't have to.Â  It's hard to outrun a storm when you've got any significant number of miles left to go and it starts thundering.Â Â 
It would be really nice to be able to get up and just hike without having to worry about so much.Â  I guess the bottom line is I'm not supposed to be worrying.Â  I'm not learning my trail lessons very quickly!!

I'm scared.Â  I've been scared for numerous reasons on this hike.Â  Scared of falling.Â  Scared of lightning, scared of getting hit by a tree falling, scared of being alone at night.Â  Now I'm scared that my hike may end.Â  I'm in pain and can barely move.Â Â Last Thursday while slack packing, my piriformis, a deep muscle in the butt cheek, started being uncomfortable with each step.Â  After a short drive, I had a hard time waking.Â  I continued hiking with varying degrees of discomfort, taking lots of Ibuprofen.Â  I decided to see a chiropractor and start some steroids yesterday.Â  Today I be did 11.5 miles and now I can barely move and I'm hurting.Â  I'm taking a zero tomorrow at Woods Hole hostel and praying I feel better.Â Â

I'm envious of the orle that don't seem to care if they are around others.Â  I tried to connect with Barbie several weeks ago, but she didn't appear interested.Â  Yet I've just heard she and Blue, I guy I met up north, just got into Pearisburg.Â  Maybe their connection was random and I'm trying to hard to make a connection with someone to hike around?Â  I am craving connection while on trail and not getting as much as I'd like.Â Â 
Nav hiked here from Angels Rest yesterday.Â  Grizz and Capt and shuttling to the TH to hike with him today.Â Â 
I've found one thing I really enjoy about being at a hostel is not only bring clean, but wearing loaner clothes!!Â  And seeing what some of the hostel help is wearing.Â  It's a very hippie ish community and what you wear doesn't seem to matter.Â  It covers you.Â  If it's got a hole or a stain, it's not a big deal, it's still functional.Â  There's something about this that appeals to me!!Â  I'm tired of being ruled by consumerism/retailism.Â  The amount of clothing I truly need is small.Â  The less I work and the less I socialize, there is a less of a concern for looking the part.Â  I don't feel I've ever been a diva, but I think my true nature is grunge!!Â  That's not exactly conducive to the area I live in.Â  They would associate that with being poor.
I see that what I want out here on trail is similar to what I think I want in life.Â  A connection with someone.Â  Yet, I haven't found anyone (not looking either) that seems to be where I am in this stage of my life.Â  Not everyone wants to live in a camper or minimilize their life.Â  I also don't want to be confined or limited.. And maybe that's what I'm seeing on trail.Â  When something doesn't suit someone they just move on.Â  I, on the other hand, feel like I'd make certain compromises to stay near someone to satisfy my need/want.Â  To what degree, I'm not sure.Â  But I'm not finding joy in a solo hike and I feel that if I were with someone and we wanted to separate yet stay together, knowing we had a plan to reconnect would really help me.Â  Now I say goodbye to people and I'm just alone.Â  I'm sure if you are reading this on the daily, it seems to be my neverending theme.Â  But I think it's been my life and now it's my trail life.Â  I just said goodbye to Nav, and I'm crying.Â  I feel left behind.Â Â 
I have little patience left for unmanaged trail and overgrowth.Â  I have little patience left for tough climbs.Â  Inclement weather.Â  I just want to walk home and be done.Â  And, as I hear happens often, I'll then be wishing to be back on trail....Â

After many tears yesterday, I made a plan.Â  I'm working on being happy with it, but it hits a lot of check lists and seems to be the best way to move forward.Â Â 
I could lie about this or not mention it, but for the sake of honesty, I will tell those reading my journal that I am skipping ahead 15.9 miles by car and taking a zero again.Â  I personally don't approve of skipping parts of the trail and calling it a thru, however, I've talked to many people and they all have their personal opinion on what a thru means to them.Â Â 
There are those that will walk past every, and I mean every white blaze, and anything less isn't a thru.Â  The are those that will yellow blaze (shuttle ahead), blue blaze (take a shorter side trail), aqua blaze (kayak the Shenandoah river) and as long as they hit Springer and Katahdin, they thru hiked.Â  My belief is feet on the AT for MOST of the trail....
My reasons for skipping this section are...
It allows be another zeroÂ 
It gets me to where I'm supposed to be at the end of the dayÂ 
It provides me with an easy water carry and help through an 18 mile dry section and a resupply at the end of it from a friend's carÂ 
It keeps me close to the guys that moved ahead yesterdayÂ 
Pink Crocs, whom I met up north, is coming to hike a few days with me.Â  She will pick me up here and will drive to the next hostel, West Feet, and spend the night.Â  Tomorrow she'll take her car to a lot where we will pass by on Sunday am.Â  I'll pick up my extra food and electronic bag from her car and will hike a bit further south before she'll need to turn around and go back to her car and head home.Â  I'll have 33 miles from her car to the next hostel then about 11 to the next.Â  During that time I can assess things.Â Â 
Kenny had insisted that if I finish this hike, he will personally get me back up here before my twelve months is up for me to complete the 15.9 mile section.Â  I have decided that I am good either way as I will finish this hike with less than 1% of missed trail.Â  I think my OCD and conscience can handle even 2% without beating myself up too bad!!Â Â 
I've had a few people tell me that not continuing my hike doesn't have to be a negative.Â  I hate even thinking that way... But is finishing in pain the way to go?Â  Will I get more accolades for walking 600 miles while hurting?Â  Have I hiked enough to open my eyes to the things I came out here to understand about myself?Â  I know one thing...I will not attempt this again.Â  I either finish it out I get to where I get and maybe section the rest, but bless those that decide to start over!!Â  The AT is a hard trail.Â  I feel I've seen very few rewards for the work I've put in.Â  The views that are few and far between have been compromised by weather and smoke.Â Â 
I do know being it here had reinforced the direction I'm taking in life.Â  I'd rather be comfortable in my clothes than wear what society tells me I should to fit in.Â  If those clothes on shy given day make me look more like a tom boy or masc lesbian, then so be it.Â  Clothing has no gender.
I want to buy better produce and make things from home, have a pantry of things I've put up....Â  That all sounds good until the actual work starts!!Â  I want to eat what I need to fuel my body and not be the glutton I haven't been.Â Â 
So this is what being out here is reinforcing in me.Â  Maybe when I get home that'll change again... But my needs/wants are very different than what most want.Â  I think I'd be good in a hippie commune (for awhile... Maybe not forever).Â Â
